title: Rebecca Ferguson won't perform at Donald Trump's inauguration due to 'uncomfortable' song choice
text:
Rebecca Ferguson won’t perform at Donald Trump’s inauguration due to ‘uncomfortable’ song choice 
The singer said there were "grey areas" about the offer that stopped her from wanting to perform Tuesday 10 January 2017 11:37 BST Click to follow Pulled out: Rebecca Ferguson will not perform at the inauguration Luca V. Teuchmann/Getty 
Rebecca Ferguson has confirmed she won’t perform at Donald Trump ’s inauguration. 
The British singer, 30, revealed last week that she had been invited to perform at the ceremony on January 20 , but said she would only take part on the condition that she could sing Strange Fruit. 
Ferguson’s request was not granted and she was left ‘uncomfortable’ with the song choice made on her behalf. 
“There are many grey areas about the offer for me to perform that I'm unable to share right now, but I will not be singing,” she said in a statement. 
“I was thrown into the middle of a political arena last week. Inauguration Ceremony update — Rebecca Ferguson (@RebeccaFMusic) January 10, 2017 
“I wasn't comfortable with the song choice made on my behalf, and although I'm very blessed to have a gift that gives me amazing opportunities, as a mother and an artist, I had to defend my stance.” 
She continued: “I requested to sing ‘Strange Fruit’ as I felt it was the only song that would not compromise my artistic integrity and also as somebody who has a lot of love for all people, but has a special empathy as well for African American people and the #blacklivesmatter movement, I wanted to create a moment of pause for people to reflect.” Michelle Obama makes emotional final speech as first lady 
Strange Fruit, which was recorded by Billie Holiday in 1939, proved controversial on its release for protesting racism and referencing the lynching of African Americans. 
Ferguson said she chose the song “to try and help educate the people watching of where division and separation can lead to if not corrected”. Read more
